Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Network Information Theory Meets Network Optimization: Optimal Linear Network Coding for Packet Erasure Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of high-rate, more efficient, and ubiquitous communication networks is a critical backbone infrastructure requirement of the 21st century. A fundamental query in studying network is thus how much information one can reliably send and how to design a scheme that attains the optimal network throughput. Presently, almost all network information theory results consist of two parts: Firstly, devising a clever solution, and then mathematically proving its optimality. Both tasks are highly non-trivial and our understanding of optimal network communications is thus still nascent. This project proposes a fundamentally new methodology, called knowledge space partition, to drastically reduce the size of the design space of network communication schemes. This allows us to use computers to systematically search for the best possible solution and automate the design of high-performance network protocols. The optimality of the resulting scheme is also guaranteed since the computer-aided search is exhaustive in nature. Based on this central idea, this project will (i) Systematically compute the linear network coding capacity for various small packet erasure networks; (ii) Design and implement optimal linear network coding protocols in practice; and (iii) Generalize the results from network-layer processing to physical-layer processing.

The new methodology will unify the concepts of stability region and capacity region, with the two concepts that having long separated the networking and information theory communities. The success of this project will also imbue next generation network engineers with back-to-basics information-theoretic thinking with enormously rich network optimization techniques. With realistic settings and implementation-friendly constructions, the optimal theoretic results of this project should spur significant developments in system-level research as well. Preliminary results of this project have shown that the network coding benefits are especially significant for the loosely-coordinated low-cost solutions operated in unlicensed bands, such as Wi-Fi. The findings of this project will thus further bridge both the domestic and global digital divide. Several sub-topics of this project, e.g., using linear algebra to improve network throughput, will be used to attract minorities and women through the Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) of Purdue, an undergraduate-research course that engages undergraduate students in a team-based hand-on research environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the driving forces that enable more efficient network communications is the continuous development of network information theory. However, finding the network capacity is a daunting task even when assuming there is no error during transmission. To mitigate the inherent hardness, this project (i) considers the practically relevant packet erasure channel model and the timely subject of causal feedback, both of which closely capture the interactive nature of today?s Internet traffic; (ii) focuses exclusively on the technique called linear network coding, one of the most promising and practical design development in the last decade; and (ii) uses the smallness and regularity of real wireless networks to circumvent the inherent hardness of the theoretical analysis. In particular, this project proposes a new design and analysis framework for network throughput optimization, which seamlessly marries the computer-science-oriented network-optimization problem with the electrical-engineering-based information-theoretic network capacity problem.  As a result, for the first time one can borrow the well-developed numerical tools in the networking and computer science communities and use them to solve the traditional physical-layer problem of throughput maximization. The proposed approach is made possible by using a new concept, called knowledge-space partition, which drastically reduces the design space and thus enables computer-based search.  Important results of this project include
(1) New network capacity characterization for small, commonly-encountered network topologies;

(2) New optimal joint network coding and network scheduling protocols for practical wireless networks, which significantly broaden the application of network coding schemes.

(3) New capacity results beyond the original packet erasure channel model.

 The overarching goal of this project is to develop new fundamental understanding of network communications through simpler but practically important network models and a novel design and analysis framework.

 

Intellectual Merit:  Combining the methodology of networking and the theoretic foundation of network information theory, this project aims to unify the concepts of the stability region and the capacity region, the two distinct objectives that have long separated networking and information theory communities. The new analysis and design framework of this project has bridged the divide and imbue next generation network engineers with back-to-basics network-information-theory-based thinking and the enormously rich network optimization techniques.  By incorporating various practical considerations into a new rigorous analytical framework, the theoretic results of this project have significantly broadened the application of wireless network coding, distributed coded storage, and coded caching to many practical scenarios.  

 

Broader Impact: The outcomes of this projects on the front of broader impacts include (i) With realistic settings and implementation-friendly constructions, the network information theory capacity results of this project will spur significant developments in system-level research, particularly in the field of wireless network scheduling and network utility maximization with network coding; (ii) Since the benefits of linear network coding are especially profound for the loosely-coordinated low-cost solutions operated in unlicensed bands, e.g., Wi-Fi, for which packet erasure is the norm, the results will further bridge both the domestic and global digital divide; (iii) Several sub-topics of this project, e.g., using linear algebra to improve network throughput, backpressure-based network coding and scheduling has been used to attract minorities and women through the Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) of Purdue, an undergraduate-research course that engages undergraduate students in a team-based hand-on research environment; (iv) The project has trained four participating Ph.D. students on information theory and network utility maximization, and one female undergraduate student on event-driven programming and network simulators; (v) 12 journal papers and 19 conference papers were supported during the duration of this project.
